raw_text:
End Bush 'denial' Blair tells EU
 
 Tony Blair is urging European leaders to wake up from their "state of denial" over President Bush's re-election.
 
 "America has spoken. The rest of the world should listen," the prime minister said in an interview with The Times newspaper, published on Friday. Mr Blair is at a summit in Brussels, where Iraq and European justice and immigration plans are on the agenda. French President Jacques Chirac reacted to his warning by saying Europe instead needed to reinforce its own unity. Mr Blair has probably been closer to President Bush than any other European leader.
 
 He said some people were in "a sort of state of denial" about the US election result but predicted a more "receptive mood" would emerge soon. America needed to listen to the world too, he said. "The fact is that President Bush is there for four years. He is there because the American people have chosen him," he argued. He also made clear he intended to take seriously what he perceives as his role in bringing the two continents together.
 
 Britain was "uniquely placed" to make out the common ground because of its strong alliance with the US, he suggested. He admitted he had gone to bed at 2230GMT, well before the American polls closed, thinking Mr Kerry might have won. He woke up at 0530GMT to discover Mr Bush had won but declined to say if he was pleased with the eventual result. His words about President Bush met a cool reception from Jacques Chirac. The French president told reporters: "Europe today has more than ever the need, the necessity, to reinforce itself and its dynamism and unity. "That is the goal of the constitution in a world that is more multi-polar than ever."
 
 Mr Chirac will miss an address to the summit from Iraqi interim leader Iyad Allawi, who this week criticised nations which took a "spectator" role to Iraq's reconstruction. Mr Chirac denied there was any snub - he is going to a memorial service for the United Arab Emirates' late leader and says he would be happy to meet Mr Allawi. He also signed a communiqué stressing the EU's commitment to securing a stable and unified Iraq. The EU also confirmed a new $21m aid package. The communiqué congratulated President Bush on his victory and stressed the importance of good transatlantic relations. The summit is also expected to agree changes to streamline European asylum and immigration decisions. Mr Blair recently said the UK would only participate in EU-wide measures where it was in UK interests but the Tories say he is surrendering a key veto. The meeting will also assess progress on the economic reform plans agreed in Lisbon in 2000 to make Europe more competitive.
llama3.2:1b: Tony Blair urged European leaders to listen to the US election result, saying that America has spoken and they should heed it. He predicted a receptive mood would emerge soon and emphasized the importance of unity in Europe. Blair stated he believed Britain was uniquely placed to identify common ground with the US due to its strong alliance.
llama3.2:3b: Tony Blair urged European leaders to wake up from their "state of denial" over President Bush's re-election, saying America has spoken and the rest of the world should listen. He believes a more receptive mood will emerge soon and that Europe needs to reinforce its own unity. France's Jacques Chirac disagreed, saying Europe's priority is to strengthen itself, while the EU confirmed a new $21m aid package for Iraq.
gemma2:2b: Tony Blair urges European leaders to recognize President Bush's re-election and emphasizes America's need to be receptive to world opinions. He acknowledges the US election result, stating that it reflects American choice. While France favors greater EU unity, Blair considers his role bridging continents crucial.  He believes Britain is uniquely positioned for common ground with the US. The summit discusses Iraq reconstruction, asylum, immigration policies, and economic reform.
qwen2.5:0.5b: In his speech to European leaders, Tony Blair warned that America has made a statement about President Bush's re-election but it is not yet clear whether it means the United States and Europe will be stronger or weaker as a result. Blair hopes this can help bring people closer together in Europe than before. He plans to work on EU projects like a constitution for a world with more countries.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Tony Blair urges European leaders to accept President Bush's re-election as America speaks, prompting calls for unity and renewed efforts to strengthen Europe's alliances with the United States. The summit in Brussels focuses on Iraq and EU justice and immigration policies. France expresses the need for strengthening Europe's dynamism, while Jacques Chirac supports continued cooperation despite criticism of the US approach.
qwen2.5:3b: Tony Blair urges European leaders to stop their "state of denial" regarding President Bush's re-election, suggesting America needs to listen to the world too. He acknowledges his close relationship with Bush but emphasizes Britain’s role in mediating tensions between continents. Despite initially thinking Kerry might win, Blair remains objective about the outcome. Meanwhile, French President Jacques Chirac advocates for European unity and stresses that Europe must reinforce its dynamism in a more multipolar world. The summit also discusses Iraq, asylum and immigration issues, and EU economic reform plans.
opencoder:1.5b:
The text provided contains key points and details about the European Union's stance on President Bush's re-election, with the aim of making a point. By summarizing it here without providing further explanations or reasoning, we can create an easily digestible version of the text.
  
Tony Blair urges European leaders to wake up from their "state of denial" over President Bush's re-election. "America has spoken," he said in The Times interview. He predicted a more "receptive mood" would emerge soon because America needed to listen to the world too. Europe today needs to reinforce itself and its dynamism and unity for the outcome to come.

deepseek-r1:1.5b:
<think>
Okay, so I need to summarize this text about Tony Blair and his message to European leaders. Let me read through it again.

The main points are that Blair is urging EU leaders to wake up because he's warning that the US won't listen. He mentions a summit in Brussels with Iraq and other immigration plans. He said some people were in denial about the election, but expect a more receptive mood. He talked about American dominance for four years, so they need to be part of it too.

Blair is closer to Bush than any other EU leader. Britain has a strong US alliance, which helps them join, while France is focused on strengthening its unity. UK leaders are skeptical, thinking Kerry might win, but when he won, they didn't express any emotion. France said the summit was important for Iraq's stability and good relations with Europe.

Chirac wasn't there to address Allali, but signed a communiqué emphasizing EU commitment to Iraq. They're also agreeing on some economic reforms. UK is only participating in EU measures where it's in their interests, which they say could limit veto power.

I think I have all the key points. Now, I'll structure this into a concise summary without any extra details or explanations.
</think>

Tony Blair has urged European leaders to act by warning that the US won't listen to President Bush. He emphasized that EU leaders should be part of the political process as the US is already dominant. The summit in Brussels included Iraq and other immigration plans, with French President Chirac focusing on strengthening EU unity. Blair mentioned that some people were in denial about the election result but expected a receptive mood soon. The United States needed to listen to the world too. Britain was uniquely placed due to its US alliance, while France signed a communiqué for Iraq's stability and European relations. The summit aims to address EU asylum and immigration changes and economic reforms. UK leaders are skeptical, with some doubtful about Kerry's win but didn't express emotion. France said the event is crucial for Iraq's future.
tinyllama:1.1b: In his interview with The Times newspaper published on Friday, British Prime Minister Tony Blair called for Europeans to wake up from their state of denial over President Bush's re-election, urging them to support policies aimed at creating a more unified and stable Iraq. He argued that America needed to listen to the rest of the world to achieve this goal, emphasizing the unique position of Britain as a strong ally with whom President Bush had good relations. During the meeting, Mr Blair also expressed frustration with Jacques Chirac's criticism of Iraqi reconstruction efforts and criticized the EU for its inability to take a more active role. The EU's new aid package and discussions on streamlining asylum and immigration decision-making were also expected to be discussed at the summit, which is set to last until Sunday.
tinydolphin:1.1b: In response to his advice on Europe's re-election, French President Jacques Chirac described the Bush presidency as "a significant period of American history." The summit, held in Brussels, is expected to cover a range of topics including Iraq, European foreign policy, and proposed changes to immigration and asylum decisions.
phi:2.7b: Tony Blair urges European leaders to listen to President Bush and take his re-election seriously, as the US has spoken. Mr Blair believes that America needs to listen to the world too. He suggests that Britain is uniquely positioned to bring Europe together due to its strong alliance with the US. Despite initially not knowing the results, Mr Blair ultimately was pleased with the eventual outcome of the election and hopes for a more receptive mood in Europe. France's President Chirac responded by saying that Europe needs to reinforce itself and its unity. The EU is expected to make changes to streamline European asylum and immigration decisions. Mr Blair recently said he would only participate in EU-wide measures if it was in UK interests, but the Conservatives say he is surrendering a key veto.
orca-mini:3b: Tony Blair urges European leaders to wake up from their "state of denial" over President Bush's re-election, saying America needs to listen to the world too. He believes Britain is uniquely placed to bring together the US and Europe and his own country is still facing issues with reconstruction in Iraq. The French president Jacques Chirac reacts to his warning by saying Europe instead needed to reinforce its unity and signaled his intention to take seriously what he perceives as his role in bringing the two continents together.
hermes3:3b: Tony Blair urges European leaders to stop "denial" about Bush's re-election, saying America has spoken and the rest of world should listen.
stablelm-zephyr:3b: Tony Blair encourages European leaders to accept President Bush's re-election and for Europe to listen to America, as it is four years with President Bush in office. He suggests Britain's strong alliance with the US makes it unique in finding common ground. French President Jacques Chirac responds that Europe has a greater need than ever to reinforce its unity and dynamism. The summit also addresses Iraq reconstruction, asylum, and immigration issues, as well as European economic reform plans agreed upon in Lisbon in 2000.
chatgpt-4o-latest: Tony Blair urged European leaders to accept President Bush's re-election and engage with the U.S., warning against a "state of denial." He emphasized Britain's unique position to bridge the U.S. and Europe due to its strong alliance with America. Blair acknowledged that while the U.S. must also listen to the world, Bush's victory reflected the American people's choice. His remarks received a cool response from French President Jacques Chirac, who stressed the need for European unity and strength. The EU summit in Brussels addressed Iraq, justice, and immigration policies, with the EU reaffirming its commitment to Iraq's stability and announcing a $21 million aid package. The summit also discussed economic reforms and asylum policies, with Blair maintaining that the UK would only support EU-wide measures beneficial to British interests.
stablelm2:1.6b: UK Prime Minister Tony Blair urges European leaders to overcome denial of US President Bush's re-election, stating that America has spoken and the world should listen. He warns against a "state of denial" among Europeans and predicts a change towards a more receptive mood will emerge soon. Britain's unique alliance with the US is highlighted as the common ground for cooperation. French President Jacques Chirac responds by emphasizing Europe's need for unity and reinforcement. The EU commits to reinforcing itself and its unity in response to the changing geopolitical landscape, while also congratulating President Bush on his victory. A new aid package and changes to streamline European asylum and immigration decisions are expected at the summit.
granite3.1-dense:2b: Tony Blair, at an EU summit in Brussels, urged European leaders to overcome their "state of denial" regarding President Bush's re-election. He emphasized that America's choice should be respected and acknowledged the need for both sides to listen to each other. Blair highlighted Britain's unique position due to its strong U.S. alliance, believing it can foster common ground between the continents. His words were met with skepticism from French President Jacques Chirac, who stressed Europe's need for unity and dynamism. The summit will address Iraq, European justice, immigration, and economic reforms, with the EU committing a $21m aid package to Iraq. Blair recently mentioned UK participation in EU-wide measures would depend on national interests, a stance disputed by opposition parties. The summit will also review progress on 2000's Lisbon agenda for European economic competitiveness.
reference: Mr Blair has probably been closer to President Bush than any other European leader.Mr Chirac denied there was any snub - he is going to a memorial service for the United Arab Emirates' late leader and says he would be happy to meet Mr Allawi.Mr Blair is at a summit in Brussels, where Iraq and European justice and immigration plans are on the agenda.Tony Blair is urging European leaders to wake up from their "state of denial" over President Bush's re-election.He woke up at 0530GMT to discover Mr Bush had won but declined to say if he was pleased with the eventual result.America needed to listen to the world too, he said.French President Jacques Chirac reacted to his warning by saying Europe instead needed to reinforce its own unity.Mr Blair recently said the UK would only participate in EU-wide measures where it was in UK interests but the Tories say he is surrendering a key veto.The French president told reporters: "Europe today has more than ever the need, the necessity, to reinforce itself and its dynamism and unity.His words about President Bush met a cool reception from Jacques Chirac.
